nodes.text: Economists' empirical estimates and integrated assessment models (IAMs) substantially underestimate economic damages from climate change and should not be used to evaluate climate risks or policy
Key methodological errors by economists lead to underestimated damages: neglect of climatic tipping points and assuming sectors not directly exposed to weather are insulated from climate change

Popular damage-function calibrations (e.g. Nordhaus DICE quadratic D(DeltaT)=a*DeltaT^2 with a≈0.00227) imply trivial global GDP losses (2.1% at 3C, 7.9% at 6C) and have been repeatedly revised downward
Scientific climate literature establishes multiple tipping elements likely to be triggered this century and cascading interactions that can amplify impacts and raise probabilities of further tipping
DICE and similar IAMs are widely used to calculate policy metrics (e.g. Social Cost of Carbon) and therefore influence government climate policy

Economists frequently used three flawed empirical methods: enumeration (sectoral summation omitting many sectors), spatial statistical proxies (using current geographic temp-income relations), and CGE models that assume market-driven adaptation toward equilibrium

Post-2014 econometric studies that attempted to correct previous methods still extrapolate historical temperature-income relationships forward and largely retain assumptions that limit damages and ignore tipping risks

Given these methodological and modelling issues, empirical estimates of damages and IAMs calibrated to them (notably DICE, FUND, PAGE) yield unreliable guidance and should be rejected for assessing climate risk and policy

Economists (Nordhaus) misrepresented Lenton et al. and used that to justify excluding tipping points from damage functions, despite Lenton et al. warning many tipping elements could be triggered this century
Assuming only weather-exposed sectors are affected led to omission of manufacturing, services and government (≈87% of economy) from damage calculations, invalidating aggregate damage estimates

Using spatial cross-sectional temperature-income relationships as proxies for temporal global warming ignores adaptation, trade smoothing, different physics of global change, and potential emergence of unprecedented extremes

Sensitivity analysis of DICE: increasing quadratic damage coefficient can produce extremely high damages (up to ~99% of GDP), cause model infeasibility at extreme values, yet within feasible ranges DICE still produces recovery paths and cannot generate endogenous economic collapse

Structural features of DICE/Ramsey framework cause saddle-path stability, full employment assumption, exogenous productivity, and abatement treated as pure economic cost, which together prevent model-based systemic collapse

Alternative damage specifications (more convex, damages to capital and TFP, inclusion of tipping probabilities) produce much larger optimal mitigation requirements and vastly larger social cost of carbon

Expert elicitation and survey evidence show wide divergence: climatologists estimate damages orders of magnitude larger than many economists, illustrating epistemic disagreement unresolved in economics literature
